Hi Mercy Montgomery, 
To answer your questions about press release and media policy there are a few places on ICMA’s website that may be of help to you! First ICMA has a Social Media Local Government Playbook, in addition to this many cities have been kind enough to share what they are doing in terms of media guidelines (put examples there). Finally a question was asked yesterday on a similar topic and I believe it may help answer your first question about press release policy. I hope you find these resources useful! 
•   This is a question that was asked yesterday about press release policy that has been answered with some helpful links that give examples of other local government’s press release policy.  http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/kn/Question/22694/Press_Release_Policy 
•   These links are case studies that show cases the Town of Avon IN and Arlington County’s media policy. These links should provide you with examples of what other local governments are doing in regards to media policy  http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/9036/Town_of_Avon_IN_Social_Media_Policy 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/6523/Arlington_County_Social_Media_Policy_and_Guidelines 
•   Finally ICMA has a Social Media Policy and Guidelines Playbook which is available to members. In this document you will find guidelines that will apply to social media specifically but they may also provide some insight into what should and should not be included in media in general.  http://icma.org/en/Page/100423/Social_Media__Local_Government_Playbook

OUTLINE OF A PRESS RELEASE
   The basic outline of a press release is as follows:
A.  Preliminaries 
   Source or organization’s name and Address
   Purpose of Release: For publication or as an invitation
   Email
   Phone number(s)
B.  Headline and subheading (if necessary)
C.  A captivating lead – This must be weaved around an attention grabber; issues that are of interest to your community, city or nation. It tells the reader why the story is of interest without saying so directly. 
D.  Body.  Here you delve into the comprehensive information on what you want the reader to know. Using the inverted pyramid formation where by you state the most important items first. Here you ask yourself suppose the editor has no space what information do want to survive his guillotine. You outline the paragraphs according  to that priority.
E.  Conclusion. You must conclude by answering the question; AND SO WHAT? This could be like a call for action or what the reader standards to gain by going through the story.
F.  Endorsement by the contact person.

SAMPLE
ABUJA GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS
No 4 Peace Drive, Area 11, Garki, Abuja, Nigeria        
To:         All Media Houses
Purpose:    For publication 
Contact:    Uzodinma Cosmas
Email:  cosdinma@yahoo.com; Cell Phone +23433311934
Date:   July 18, 2013
Subject: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT: PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE CANVASSES PROACTIVE DISCLOSURE; COMMENDS AGIS
House Committee Chairman on Reform of Government Institutions, Hon. Matthew Omegara, has charged government ministries, department and agencies (MDAs) to take proactive disclosure measures to ensure the effective implementation of the Freedom of Information Act in their organizations. The Committee Chairman, gave this charge while commending the Abuja Geographic Information Systems, AGIS, for positive efforts in this direction.
Hon. Omegara gave this charge recently during an interactive session with the AGIS Executive Director, Mrs. Jamilah Tangaza  at the National Assembly Complex. According to him, the session was designed to find out how government institutions were doing with regards to the implementation of the FOI Act. Government institutions, the Committee Chairman said, should take steps to improve their status of compliance with the FOI Act. He also reiterated the provision in the Act requiring MDAs to send Annual Reports on the status of their compliance with the Act to the Office of the Attorney General of the Federation.     
The Hon. Omegara, paid glowing tributes to the Director General, National Electricity Regulatory Commission (NERC), Dr. Sam Amadi, for the work the Commission has done to ensure full compliance with the Act; a factor which has made the Committee to appoint the DG as its consultant on the subject.
AGIS, he said, is an agency that has a lot to with the FOI Act because Nigerians, he noted, are eager to know how to acquire land in FCT, how to process applications, availability of plots, fees payable in regards to the different layout and , revocation information etc. Other areas that might be of public interest, he pointed out, are revenue generation capacity of AGIS, sources of such revenues and how they are disbursements.
Earlier in her brief on the status of AGIS compliance with the Act, the Executive Director, AGIS, Mrs. Jamilah Tangaza stated that in compliance with this all important Act, AGIS is embarking on a new public communication road map to ensure a proactive disclosure of items covered under the FOI Act. Highlights of the Road-map, she revealed, include: regular customer forums; no-wrong-door approach to customer service – under which every officer should know the agency so well as to serve as effective guide and information resource to members of the public. 
She also disclosed that the new plan will ensure the maintenance of both electronic and print data-bank for effective storage and retrieval of information for public access. Other measures include the deployment of dynamic and interactive online content and effective use of media houses with brilliant communication copies and productions among others for public enlightenment and information.
The Executive Director also informed the House Committee that FCT Administration has FOI Committee domiciled in the Department of Economic Planning, Research and Statistics and that AGIS does not disburse revenue it realized but moves them to the FCT IGR vaults as at when due.   
The Executive Director therefore pledged her AGIS Commitment to abiding by the ideals of the Freedom of Information Act as well as deploying best practice self delivery also revealed that the agency has a demonstrated interest in partnering with genuine organizations with the objective of promoting public awareness on the FOI Act. She informed the Committee that recently AGIS supported the Young Journalist Forum of the Nigeria Union of Journalists in their workshop, designed to update selected young journalists on the Freedom of Information Act. 
Uzodinma Cosmas
Assistant Director Information

author: Mercy Montgomery
text:
The City of Hamilton, OH is working to formulate a citywide policy to ensure that press releases and media contacts are standardized across departments and divisions. 
Does anyone have a sample press release with descriptions of information to include (and not to include)? We're hoping to create a document that can be distributed to all departments that illustrates essential considerations and key information to include.
Any advice regarding best practices would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks in advance!
Mercy Montgomery
City Manager's Office
title: Standardized Media/Press Release Policy
